# Testing :: nasty filenames, also on UNIX

An example of some filenames which caused trouble on a Linux (Ubuntu) box, due to filename(!) size limitations on Linux, which were not a problem on NTFS/MSWindows (as reported by Linux `rsync`):

```
rsync: [generator] recv_generator: failed to stat "/media/root/16TB_DSK06/16TB03CX1/16TB03CX1.8/6TB.recovery.1/Qiqqa/SopKonijn/Qiqqa-exports-dir/docs/UNKNOWN - \#345\#242\#236\#347\#233\#212\#345\#200\#274-\#344\#277\#241\#345\#217\#267\#346\#236\#201\#346\#200\#247\#344\#273\#245\#345\#217\#212\#346\#233\#264\#346\#226\#260\#351\#200\#237\#347\#216\#207\#347\#232\#204\#351\#200\#211\#346\#213\#251\#345\#217\#257\#347\#224\#250\#344\#270\#262\#350\#241\#214\#350\#276\#223\#345\#205\#245\#345\#217\#243\#347\#224\#261\#350\#275\#257\#344\#273\#266\#346\#235\#245\#351\#205\#215\#350\#207\#265-\#350\#257\#245\#345\#231\#250\#344\#273\#266\#350\#277\#230\#345\#214\#205\#346\#213\#254\#350\#207\#252\#346\#240\#241\#345\#207\#206\#345\#222\#214\#347\#263\#273\#347\#273\#237\#346\#240\#241\#345\#207\#206\#351\#200\#211\#351\#241\#271-\#344\#273\#245\#346\#266\#210\#351\#231\#244\#345\#231\#250\#344\#273\#266\#346\#234\#254\#350\#272\#253\#346\#210\#226\#347\#263\#273\#347\#273\#237\#347\#232\#204\#345\#242\#236\#347\#233\#212\#345\#222\#214\#345\#201\#217\#347\#247\#273\#350\#257\#257\#345\#267\#256- CMOS \#347\#273\#223\#346\#236\#204\#347\#241\#256\#344\#277\#235\#345\#231\#250\#344\#273\#266\#345\#205\#267\#346\#234\#211\#346\#236\#201\#344\#275\#216\#345\#212\#237\#350\#200\#227-\#346\#216\#211\#347\#224\#265\#346\#250\#241\#345\#274\#217\#345\#207\#217\#345\#260\#221\#347\#255\#211\#345\#276\#205\#346\#227\#266\#347\#232\#204\#345\#212\#237\#350\#200\#227\#350\#207\#263.pdf": File name too long (36)
rsync: [generator] recv_generator: failed to stat "/media/root/16TB_DSK06/16TB03CX1/16TB03CX1.8/6TB.recovery.1/Qiqqa/SopKonijn/Qiqqa-exports-dir/docs_original/UNKNOWN - \#345\#242\#236\#347\#233\#212\#345\#200\#274-\#344\#277\#241\#345\#217\#267\#346\#236\#201\#346\#200\#247\#344\#273\#245\#345\#217\#212\#346\#233\#264\#346\#226\#260\#351\#200\#237\#347\#216\#207\#347\#232\#204\#351\#200\#211\#346\#213\#251\#345\#217\#257\#347\#224\#250\#344\#270\#262\#350\#241\#214\#350\#276\#223\#345\#205\#245\#345\#217\#243\#347\#224\#261\#350\#275\#257\#344\#273\#266\#346\#235\#245\#351\#205\#215\#350\#207\#265-\#350\#257\#245\#345\#231\#250\#344\#273\#266\#350\#277\#230\#345\#214\#205\#346\#213\#254\#350\#207\#252\#346\#240\#241\#345\#207\#206\#345\#222\#214\#347\#263\#273\#347\#273\#237\#346\#240\#241\#345\#207\#206\#351\#200\#211\#351\#241\#271-\#344\#273\#245\#346\#266\#210\#351\#231\#244\#345\#231\#250\#344\#273\#266\#346\#234\#254\#350\#272\#253\#346\#210\#226\#347\#263\#273\#347\#273\#237\#347\#232\#204\#345\#242\#236\#347\#233\#212\#345\#222\#214\#345\#201\#217\#347\#247\#273\#350\#257\#257\#345\#267\#256- CMOS \#347\#273\#223\#346\#236\#204\#347\#241\#256\#344\#277\#235\#345\#231\#250\#344\#273\#266\#345\#205\#267\#346\#234\#211\#346\#236\#201\#344\#275\#216\#345\#212\#237\#350\#200\#227-\#346\#216\#211\#347\#224\#265\#346\#250\#241\#345\#274\#217\#345\#207\#217\#345\#260\#221\#347\#255\#211\#345\#276\#205\#346\#227\#266\#347\#232\#204\#345\#212\#237\#350\#200\#227\#350\#207\#263.pdf": File name too long (36)
```


Also note that UNIX/Linux apparently has a (hard?) 256 character filename limit; the question being if this 256 *bytes* or 256 *codepoints* as most of the badly breaking files I've seen have Chinese names.
